channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Missile Strike on Kyiv Kills 3
item.description: Air defenses intercepted the missiles just six minutes after alarms sounded, leaving people little time to react. The authorities were investigating after a mother and child were killed by debris while trying to get into a shelter.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Municipal workers clearing debris from apartments near the clinic compound.

item.title: The Nonstop Work of Ukrainian Air Defenses: ‘We Have No Days Off’
item.description: Russian air attacks on Kyiv have come in relentless waves. Yet very little has penetrated the patched-together but increasingly sophisticated air defense network. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen demonstrated working on a mobile air defense system responsible for protecting a patch of sky just outside Kyiv.

item.title: Conflict With the Far Right Shrouds Jerusalem’s Pride Parade
item.description: Much of Israel’s L.G.B.T.Q. community feels threatened by the right-wing government and its judicial overhaul plan — even with a gay speaker of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The pride parade last year in Jerusalem.

item.title: Australia’s Most Decorated Soldier Loses War Crime Defamation Case
item.description: A judge ruled for newspapers that had been accused of defaming the soldier by reporting that he had committed war crimes in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ben Roberts-Smith in Sydney last year.

item.title: China Wants to Set the Terms of Any ‘Thaw’ With the U.S.
item.description: China has pushed to set the terms of its re-engagement with the Biden administration, rebuffing a request for a defense meeting while urging Washington to drop sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
German Marshall Fund of the United States
item.media:description: Beijing rejected an invitation for China’s defense minister, Li Shangfu, to meet with Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin at a security meeting this weekend in Singapore.

item.title: Senegal’s Opposition Leader Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
item.description: A case involving a rape charge against Ousmane Sonko has monopolized the country’s political life and raised concerns over the prosecution of political opponents.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Ousmane Sonko addressing supporters in Dakar, Senegal, in March.

item.title: Individual Canadian Cigarettes to Be Labeled With Health Warnings
item.description: Tobacco companies must soon label individual cigarettes sold in the country with a health warning, in what Canada is calling a global first.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: Ireland Worries That Brexit Will Ruin Fishing Industry
item.description: Along Ireland’s coast, fishing has been a way of life for generations. But changes to the industry — including a cut in quotas after Brexit and a government plan to scrap boats — may see a way of life disappear.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: A crew member aboard the fishing vessel Aquila in April on its final voyage.

item.title: Honeybee Swarms Darken U.K. Skies, Sending Beekeepers Scrambling
item.description: It’s swarming season in Britain, with honeybee colonies splitting in half in search of new homes. This year, beekeepers say they are getting an unusually high number of swarm sightings.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Ian Campbell, via The British Beekeepers Association
item.media:description: A swarm of bees collected at St. Francis church in Newcastle upon Tyne, England.

item.title: Female Wrestlers in India Threaten to Toss Olympic Medals in Protest
item.description: Their protest dispersed, female wrestlers who have accused a powerful official of sexual harassment went to the Ganges intending to throw away their Olympic medals.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Vinesh Phogat, center, and other wrestlers clashed with the police as they tried to march to the new Parliament building on Sunday in New Delhi.

item.title: Fear Sets In Among Turkey’s L.G.B.T. Community After Erdogan’s Attacks
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan vilified gay people during his re-election campaign, calling them a threat to society and rallying conservatives against them. It has left people feeling threatened, and alone.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Elif Ince, Safak Timur and Sergey Ponomarev
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Drag artists applying makeup before a performance in a club in Istanbul in May.

item.title: Sudan’s Army Withdraws From Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The move deals a blow to efforts to end the war and deliver humanitarian aid to millions of people nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Yemenis who fled Sudan disembarked from the Saudi ship Abha at Jeddah port in May.

item.title: Israel Called Them ‘Precision’ Strikes. But Civilian Homes Were Hit, Too.
item.description: Palestinians in Gaza say that Israel’s strikes against Islamic Jihad amount to a collective punishment aimed at making them fearful about who their neighbors might be.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Samar Abu Elouf
item.media:description: A hole left by a bomb that entered the home of the Khoswan family, in a strike on an Islamic Jihad member who lived below, in Gaza City.

item.title: Triggered by North Korea, South Korea’s False Evacuation Alert Causes Chaos
item.description: South Koreans said the alert, which was triggered by a North Korean rocket launch, showed that their country was unprepared to respond to a real emergency.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Victoria Kim and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Watching a news broadcast with file footage of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, at the Seoul Railway Station in Seoul on Wednesday.

item.title: The House Passed the Bill. Who Won?
item.description: President Biden both won and lost the debt-ceiling negotiation.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Biden.

item.title: Iceland Is a Magnet for Tourists. Its First Lady Has Some Advice for Them.
item.description: Eliza Reid, a former U.N. tourism ambassador and the wife of President Gudni Johannesson, welcomes her country’s many visitors, and has a few suggestions on safety, respect and how to meet locals.
item.dc:creator: Paige McClanahan

item.title: China Investing in Open-Source Intelligence Collection on the U.S.
item.description: A new report outlines Chinese efforts to mine public information from the Pentagon, think tanks and private companies to gain insight on the American military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: American service members flying a Navy reconnaissance plane over the South China Sea in 2018.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s response to drone strikes on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Some of the apartment buildings damaged after a drone attack in Moscow.

item.title: Russia Strikes Kyiv, Killing 3 in Another Early Morning Attack
item.description: At least one child was among the dead, local officials said. Russia has recently increased the pace and intensity of its strikes on the Ukrainian capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Nicole Tung and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency personnel at a clinic compound in Kyiv, Ukraine, after a Russian attack on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Denounces West Over Drone Strike on Moscow
item.description: Kremlin officials said Ukraine’s allies should have condemned the strike, and argued again that its real war was with the West.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Police officers stood outside several apartment buildings damaged after a drone attack in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Is Still Haunted by Boris Johnson and Liz Truss
item.description: Boris Johnson’s misadventures still make headlines, but Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s bigger problem is high inflation and soaring bond yields reminiscent of those that toppled Liz Truss.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain leaving 10 Downing Street this month.

item.title: U.S. Adds Aid to Ukraine to Deliver Ammunition for Drones and Artillery
item.description: The move to send $300 million in additional support comes as Moscow has come under drone attacks in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a Stinger anti-aircraft missile near a frontline position in Donetsk last year.

item.title: As Iran Seizes Tankers, UAE Pulls Back From US-Led Maritime Force
item.description: The United Arab Emirates announced it had stopped participating in the security group after Iran seized two tankers in the Persian Gulf recently.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aboard the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln in the northern Arabian Sea, in 2019.

item.title: Readers in Asia: What Does L.G.B.T.Q. Life Look Like Where You Live?
item.description: We may include your response in a June edition of the Asia Pacific Morning Briefing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pride in Chennai, India, last June.

item.title: Climate Change and Russia Spell Trouble for NATO Up North
item.description: Russia may be having major difficulties in Ukraine, but it remains a vast power in the north and the Arctic, where climate change is opening new sea routes for trade and trouble.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The missile cruiser Peter the Great, part of the Russian Navy’s northern fleet, at its Arctic base in Severomorsk in 2021. Russia, China and the West are all seeking to expand their military presence in the Arctic.

item.title: How to Lower Deaths Among Women? Give Away Cash.
item.description: Mortality rates fell by 20 percent among women in countries that began cash transfer programs to the poor. Children also benefited.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Omar Havana for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and her 1-year-old son in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The new analysis collected information on cash transfer programs and death rates in 37 countries.

item.title: Germany Closes Four of Its Five Russian Consulates After Moscow Dispute
item.description: Berlin responds to the Kremlin limiting the number of German diplomatic staff allowed in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Berlin will remain open, while four of its five consulates in Germany will be forced to close.

item.title: A Big Day for the Debt Ceiling
item.description: The bipartisan debt limit deal still isn’t assured of passing.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif. Speaks following his meeting with President Joe Biden in the Oval Office early last week.

item.title: German Court Convicts 4 Leftists in Attacks Targeting Neo-Nazis
item.description: A 28-year-old woman and three accomplices were sentenced to prison for their roles in a series of attacks on people they considered neo-Nazis.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Lina E., second from right, and three co-defendants covered their faces during a court hearing in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: India Will Scrap 2,000 Rupee Notes, Echoing 2016 Demonetization
item.description: The move to retire 2,000-rupee notes, worth $24, has triggered bad memories of a similar campaign in 2016. It has also left some businesses short of change.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Sanchit Khanna/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Customers exchanging 2,000-rupee notes at a bank in New Delhi last week.

item.title: State Farm Stops Offering Insurance in California
item.description: The largest insurer in California said it would stop offering new coverage. It’s part of a broader trend of companies pulling back from dangerous areas.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle, Jill Cowan and Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A firefighter tried to save a home in Meyers, Calif., in 2021.

item.title: Pakistan Courts Challenge Military With High-Profile Rulings
item.description: Long seen as kowtowing to the military, the judiciary has defied it in recent rulings, signaling an important shift in Pakistan’s political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Paramilitary soldiers in front of the Supreme Court during a ruling on former Prime Minister Imran Khan, in Islamabad, Pakistan, earlier this month.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Drone attacks on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Inspecting the damaged facade of an apartment building after a drone attack in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Drones Strike Moscow Civilian Areas, a First in Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: At least eight drones were intercepted, the Kremlin said, but the foray raised questions about Russian air defenses.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ivan Nechepurenko and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: Inspecting the damaged facade of an apartment building after a drone attack in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: North Korea Says Rocket Launch Failed After It Triggers Alerts in South Korea
item.description: The North’s rocket was said to carry a spy satellite, enabling it to watch its enemies more closely. But it said Wednesday that the launch had failed.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Residents in Seoul watched as news of North Korea’s plan to launch a spy satellite was shown on television.

item.title: Debt Deal Includes a Green Light for a Contentious Pipeline
item.description: Climate activists are livid over a provision in the debt limit agreement that orders federal agencies to issue permits for the Mountain Valley Pipeline — and says courts can’t review them.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Melissa Golden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pipes on Brush Mountain in Virginia that have sat for years at a stalled section of the Mountain Valley Pipeline project.

item.title: Fluorescein Turned Venice Grand Canal Green, Officials Say
item.description: A chemical used in underwater construction and medical procedures was used to dye parts of the channel bright green, but the authorities still don’t know how it got there.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: The authorities said that fluorescein, a chemical used in underwater construction, turned part of the Grand Canal in Venice a phosphorescent shade of green in recent days.

item.title: Wildfire Near Halifax, Nova Scotia, Leads to Evacuation of More Than 16,000
item.description: Wildfires in Nova Scotia have heightened the sense of unease as blazes also burn in the west of the country.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Meagan Campbell
item.media:credit: Kelly Clark/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Thick plumes of smoke rising from an out-of-control fire on Sunday that forced the evacuation of residents in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

item.title: NATO Troops and Ethnic Serbs Clash in Kosovo: What to Know
item.description: Clashes in northern Kosovo that injured dozens of ethnic Serbs and NATO soldiers are the latest flare up in a long-running standoff between Kosovo and Serbia.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: NATO officers and ethnic Serbs clashed in Zvecan, Kosovo, on Monday.

item.title: A Plan to Avert a Vast Oil Spill Off Yemen Moves Ahead
item.description: A decaying tanker holds about four times the amount of oil leaked in the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster. Experts have warned that it is an ecological time bomb that could explode or disintegrate at any moment.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: The FSO Safer, a supertanker off the coast of Yemen, in an undated image from a video. If all goes as planned, an inspection of the ship will pave the way for an operation to transfer its oil to a seaworthy tanker.

item.title: The I.A.E.A. takes its case for securing the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant to the U.N. Security Council.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: A team from the International Atomic Energy Agency at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in March.

item.title: Erdogan Pushed to Victory in Turkey by Conservative Women
item.description: In winning another term as Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan was propelled to victory in part by the fervent support of an often underappreciated constituency — conservative religious women.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Elif Ince
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turkish women holding a banner with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s picture at a rally in Istanbul before he was re-elected.

item.title: The Impact of the Moscow Drone Strike Is Psychological, Russian Military Commentators Say
item.description: The Kremlin says the Defense Ministry responded well to the attack, but critics argue that the assault shows a lack of leadership from a government that promised only a “special military operation” in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Police officers near a damaged apartment building in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Summer Heat
item.description: Why the next few months may be hotter than normal.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: People crowd the beaches in The Rockaways in July 2021.

item.title: Moscow Drone Attack: What We Know
item.description: Russia’s Defense Ministry said that at least eight drones had targeted Moscow and the surrounding region.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Several buildings in Moscow were damaged early Tuesday. The intended target of the attack was not immediately clear.

item.title: A Journey Across London on the Elizabeth Line
item.description: The new rail line lets travelers leave the city’s tourist-clogged core and embark on fast, inexpensive journeys to fascinating outer-London destinations, from a bustling market town to a hub of South Asian culture.
item.dc:creator: Mark Vanhoenacker
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Northeast of Heathrow, Southall is a hub of South Asian culture. Visitors can see one of Europe’s largest Sikh temples, sample South Asian cuisine and peruse shops selling jewelry, clothing and other goods.

item.title: Germany’s Tenuous Coalition Government Shows Strain
item.description: Tensions in the three-party government have built for months. But the latest sniping is unusually fierce, raising fresh questions of dysfunction.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant in Karlsruhe, Germany, in 2022.

item.title: Alberta Election Sees Conservatives Keep Power After Hard-Right Turn
item.description: But the United Conservative Party will hold substantially fewer seats in the legislature, in an apparent rebuff of the politics of its outspoken leader.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: Danielle Smith, Alberta’s premier and the leader of the United Conservative Party, on Monday night.

item.title: Why Did The Financial Times Kill a #MeToo Scoop on the Observer Columnist Nick Cohen?
item.description: Seven women say that a star columnist groped them or made unwanted sexual advances. But Britain’s news media has a complicated relationship with outing its own.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy Siegle is one of multiple women to accuse the British columnist Nick Cohen of unwanted sexual advances and groping.

item.title: At Guantánamo’s Court Like No Other, Progress Is Frustrated by State Secrets
item.description: The U.S. government is still sorting out what’s secret in an Indonesian bombing case more than two decades after the attack.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Some information about the Guantánamo prison and about C.I.A. black-site detention is also unmentionable in open court.

item.title: Would Large Language Models Be Better If They Weren’t So Large?
item.description: Teaching fewer words to large language models might help them sound more human.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Assaults on Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainians taking cover inside a subway station during an air raid alert in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Russia Targets Kyiv With Third Wave of Strikes in 24 Hours, Killing One
item.description: The attack came after a rare daytime assault on Monday. Russia has stepped up attacks on the capital this month as Ukraine prepares for a counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents outside an apartment building damaged by a Russian drone strike, in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Guyanese Teenager Is Charged With 19 Counts of Murder in School Dorm Fire
item.description: Investigators have accused the 15-year-old student of starting the blaze in anger after her mobile phone was confiscated.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Mahdia Secondary School in Mahdia, Guyana, was gutted by a fire that officials said had been deliberately set.

item.title: Russian Guards Beat and Tortured Kherson Prisoners, Leading to Deaths
item.description: Ukraine has charged four members of Russia’s National Guard with war crimes in Kherson. The four acted with such impunity, the authorities say, they did not mask their identities.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Petro Zhadan, a former soldier, was held for 73 days and heavily beaten at a detention center in Kherson, Ukraine. “All my body was blue,” he said.

item.title: Kyiv Residents Scramble for Shelter From Daytime Russia Missile Barrage
item.description: A drone attack on Tuesday came after a barrage of missiles on Monday sent schoolchildren running for shelter as explosions echoed across the Ukrainian capital, rare daytime aerial assaults on the city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients and medical staff members taking shelter in the basement of a hospital in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: A Climactic Opening
item.description: Floods, landslides and fires are making it harder to get national parks ready for summer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson

item.title: Spanish Prime Minister Calls Snap Election for July
item.description: Pedro Sánchez, who leads a fragile coalition government, made the announcement after his liberal party lost ground to conservatives in regional and local elections over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain, shown at the White House on May 12, said he would dissolve Parliament and hold elections on July 23.

item.title: She Said Her Professor Sexually Harassed Her. His Wife Won Damages.
item.description: A case involving a graduate student and her art history professor illustrates the tangled state of sexual power dynamics in Japan.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meiko Sano, who brought a sexual harassment lawsuit against her art history professor, in Tokyo.
